coredata.dc:title: Effect of Bi2O3 content on mechanical and nuclear radiation shielding properties of Bi2O3-MoO3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 glass system
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:creator: Issa, Shams A.M.
Ahmad, Mahmoud
Tekin, H.O.
Saddeek, Yasser B.
Sayyed, M.I.
coredata.dc:description: The melt quench method has been used to prepare the xBi2O3-(30-x)MoO3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass system, where x = 15, 17.5, 20, 25 and 30 mol. %. In the energy range of 0.015–15 MeV, the mass attenuation coefficient (μm), half value layer (HVL) and effective atomic number (Zeff) values have been calculated using MCNPX code for prepared glasses. Using the Geometric progression (G–P) fitting method the exposure buildup factor (EBF) and energy absorption buildup factor (EABF) have been computed. In addition, the removal cross-section (ΣR) values for fast neutrons have been evaluated. Moreover, the mass attenuation coefficient for different compositions glasses have been calculated using XMuDat program and XCOM and have been compared with MCNPX values. The μm, HVL and ΣR values of the investigated glass samples have been compared with the different types of concretes in other glass materials. Using the pulse-echo technique, the elastic moduli for glass samples have been measured. The glass sample 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 shows the highest values of μm and lowest values of HVL, which indicate that this glass composition is the most effective at radiation shielding.

XMuDat
Elastic moduli

article.ce:title: Effect of Bi2O3 content on mechanical and nuclear radiation shielding properties of Bi2O3-MoO3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 glass system

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The melt quench method has been used to prepare the xBi2O3-(30-x)MoO3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass system, where x = 15, 17.5, 20, 25 and 30 mol. %. In the energy range of 0.015–15 MeV, the mass attenuation coefficient (μm), half value layer (HVL) and effective atomic number (Zeff) values have been calculated using MCNPX code for prepared glasses. Using the Geometric progression (G–P) fitting method the exposure buildup factor (EBF) and energy absorption buildup factor (EABF) have been computed. In addition, the removal cross-section (ΣR) values for fast neutrons have been evaluated. Moreover, the mass attenuation coefficient for different compositions glasses have been calculated using XMuDat program and XCOM and have been compared with MCNPX values. The μm, HVL and ΣR values of the investigated glass samples have been compared with the different types of concretes in other glass materials. Using the pulse-echo technique, the elastic moduli for glass samples have been measured. The glass sample 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 shows the highest values of μm and lowest values of HVL, which indicate that this glass composition is the most effective at radiation shielding.

ce:section.ce:para: Indirectly ionizing high energy radiation such as photons and directly ionizing high energy radiation, such as protons, alpha particles, and electrons, have found broad application in radiation technology, medicine and medical applications, space technology and radiation physics. Therefore, suitable nuclear radiation shielding for researchers and their surrounding instruments has been a continuous problem [1]. Currently, unique kinds of concretes are being used at nuclear power plants and nuclear wastes stockpiles for security against nuclear radiation and to protect from different types of high energy nuclear radiations. Although concretes have a low cost and offer a flexible structure, which is necessary for the engineering of buildings, they have a few disadvantages as well. Concrete varieties, like the variety in their creation and the one presented in this study, can vary in their water content; higher contents of water causes the detriment of concretes’ basic quality and a decrease in its density. Further, the concrete will lose water when exposed to nuclear radiation because of the heat released from nuclear radiation energy. Furthermore, concrete’s high opacity makes it very difficult to observe its radiation shielding properties [2].

In such manner, glass materials function as highly effective neutron and gamma ray absorbers, and their transparency to visible light provides a substitution to nuclear radiation shields for researchers [3]. The glass materials also offer some features such as easy alteration of its properties by composition changes and a capability to glaze products of radioactive materials for long-time. The glass materials are favored by many researchers as the nuclear radiation shields [1,4–15]. Because of the presence of BiO6, MoO4 and MoO6 groups in the glass network formation, the bismuth trioxide, and molybdenum trioxide appear as the formers of the non-conventional network. The bismuth borate-based glass has highly broad applications such as for laser host fibers and for photonic switches. Due to a particular glass composition and a high polarizability of bismuth trioxide, these glasses present a high range of the refractive index (1.8–2.5) and high energy gaps, which allows their use in the broad spectral range from ultraviolet up to infrared. New possibilities could open up to extend the properties of these materials due to the presence of bismuth, borate oxides, molybdenum trioxide, vanadium pentoxide and ferric oxide [16]. In this work the μm values have been computed by using MCNPX in the energy range of 0.015–15 MeV and have been compared with XCOM and XMuDat programs of glasses within the Bi2O3-MoO3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 system. Moreover, the Zeff, HVL, EBF, EABF and ΣR values have been computed as well as elastic moduli.

The μm values of all investigated glass samples have been computed according to the following equation [17]:

The minimum half value layer (HVL) values are required for radiation shielding design. The following equation has been used to compute the HVL values [1,19]:

ce:section.ce:section-title: MCNPX code, XCOM and XMuDat program
ce:section.ce:para:
The frequency of applications of mathematical methods is increasing day-by-day to solve different physical problems. The Monte Carlo simulation code model simulates the experimental environment while considering the physical and geometrical properties of tools, cross-section values, and different databases have been taken from experimental studies. The literature review observed that MCNP code has been utilized by various researchers to study the μm of different type of glass materials [4,11,13,27–36]. Therefore, in addition to XCOM results, MCNPX (Monte Carlo N-Particle Transport Code System-extended) general aim Monte Carlo code has been utilized to study μm values of glass samples considering the Lambert-Beer law:
(10)
I =
I o
e x
p
( - μ t )
where Io and t are the incident intensity and path length. Fig. 1 shows the 3-D view (obtained from MCNPX Visual Editor VE) of gamma-ray attenuation setup of MCNPX with prime simulation equipment like point isotropic radiation source, a lead collimator for primary radiation beam, attenuator glass samples, F4 tally mesh detection field and Pb blocks to avoid detection field from scattered radiation. The analysis of a recent study has been completed utilizing the D00205ALLCP03 MCNPXDATA package is included of DLC-200/MCNPDATA cross-section libraries. This library typically extends ENDF/B-VI data from 2 × 104 to 15 × 104 keV. The NPS variable is set as 100 mega particles. XCOM and XMuDat databases are given which can be utilized to compute the photon cross-sections due to interaction processes (scattering, photoelectric absorption, and pair production), and total attenuation coefficients, for the element, compound or mixture, at wide energies. XCOM program utilizes the Hubbell-Seltzer database while XMuDat program utilizes both Hubbell-Seltzer and Boone-Chavez data to calculate the μm values [7].

The melt quenching technique has been utilized to prepare the xBi2O3-(30-x)MoO3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass system, where x = 15, 17.5, 20, 25 and 30 mol. To obtain the fine powder, the pure quantities (Aldrich 99.8%) of bismuth trioxide (Bi2O3), molybdenum trioxide (MoO3), boric acid (H3BO3), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), silicon dioxide (SiO2) and ferric oxide (Fe2O3) have been combined by crushing. Under normal atmosphere and by utilizing a porcelain melting-pot, the powder has been melted in an electrically heated oven at about 1373 K for about one hour. The investigated glass samples have been created by quench and dissolve on a pre-heated mold, which is promptly transported to another oven to anneal the samples at 773 K for two hours. The opposite sides of designed glasses with the thickness 10 mm have been fitted to be appropriate for mechanical measurements. The Philips X-ray (PW/1710) with the power of Cu-Kα radiation and Ni-filter at 30 mA and 40 × 103 V, has been used to examine the structure of glass samples. Using the toluene immersion fluid, the Archimedes process has been utilized to measure the densities of samples. The X- and Y-cut transducers (KARL DEUTSCH Echograph model 1085), which operated at 4 × 106 Hz, have been used to measure the longitudinal ultrasonic velocity (VL) and shear ultrasonic velocity (VS) with ± 10 m/s uncertainty.

Density (ρ) and chemical composition for studied samples have been listed in Table 1
. The density values of the samples have been measured using the Archimedes method, described as the following [37]:
(11)
ρ =
a
a - b
×
ρ T
where a and b are the weights of the sample in air and toluene, respectively, and ρT is the toluene density (0.867 g/cm3). As shown in Fig. 2 , the density values of glass samples increase from 3.053 to 3.722 (g/cm3) with the content of Bi2O3 increases from 15 to 30 mol %. This behavior may be due to Bi2O3 having the highest atomic weight (465.959 g/mol) of other components, hence, the glass network becomes denser. Due to the absence of crystallization peaks as shown in Fig. 3 , it signified that the prepared glasses are amorphous in nature.

Fig. 4 shows that the μm values against photon energy for xBi2O3-(30-x)MoO3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass system, where x = 15, 17.5, 20, 25 and 30 mol. It is clear that the μm values are at their maximum at 0.015 MeV (low energy) for the samples. Where the photoelectric effect is predominant, the values of μm ranged from 21.06 to 33.75 g/cm2 as the concentration of Bi2O3 increases. The μm values for investigated glasses decrease rapidly with increasing incident energy. In the energy range, 0.3–3 MeV, where Compton Effect is the predominate process, the values of μm glasses vary in a narrow range. When the energy becomes higher than 3 MeV, the μm values of all studied glass samples appear to be constant, which may be due to the process of pair production being dominant [38]. As shown in Fig. 4, the curves peak at 90.53 keV due to the K-shell absoption of Bi element. The μm values, which were obtained using MCNPX code (version 2.4.0), are compared with the data obtained by using XCOM and XMuDat program, which are listed in Table 2 . As listed in Table 2, the values showed that the XCOM data generally agreed well with both MCNPX Monte Carlo and XMuDat values. The following equations have been used to calculate the difference (Δ) between XCOM data and both MCNPX Monte Carlo and XMuDat values (Table 2):
(12)
Δ 1
=
XCOM - X M u D a t
XCOM
× 100
%
(13)
Δ 2
=
XCOM - M C N P X
XCOM
× 100
%

Fig. 5 shows the partial interactions coefficient for the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample against photon energy. As seen in this figure, at low photon energy (0.015–0.2 MeV) the photoelectric absorption has only a strong effect on the total μm values for the glassy sample. As the photon energy increases, the coherent and incoherent scattering start affecting the total μm values, where the effect of coherent scattering is weaker than the incoherent scattering. At the photon energy range 1.5 MeV, the effect of pair production (in nuclear and electronic fields) starts to appear on total μm values, where the effect of pair production in the nuclear field is stronger than pair production in the electronic field on total μm values. Tables 3–7
observe the total μm values and partial interaction values of G1, G2, G3, G4, and G5 glass samples, respectively. As listed in these tables, the effect of partial interaction on total μm values increases as the Bi2O3 contained increases from 15 to 30 mol. %. The contribution (%) of partial interaction values on the total partial interaction values at 0.015, 1.5 and 15 MeV for G1, G2, G3, G4, and G5 glass sample are listed in Table 8 . Fig. 6 shows the mass attenuation coefficient of G5 glass sample, ordinary (OC), hematite-serpentine (HSC) and steel-scrap (SSC) concretes [39] with the photon energy. As shown in this figure, the μm values of the G5 glass sample are higher than that for OC, HSC and SSC concretes. Fig. 7 observes the μm difference between the G5 glass sample and GR1 (66B2O3-5Al2O3-29Na2O) [13], GR2 (5Bi2O3-61B2O3-5Al2O3-29Na2O) [13], GR3 (10PbO-20SiO2-46.67B2O3-23.33Na2O) [11], GR4 (15PbO-15SiO2-46.67B2O3-23.33Na2O) [11] and GR5 (20Bi2O3-46B2O3-5Al2O3-29Na2O) [13] glass samples with photon energy. It is clear that the μm values’ difference between the G5 glass sample and GR1, GR2, GR3, GR4, and GR5 glass samples decrease with energy increase, up to 1.5 MeV, and then increase with photon energy. As seen the Fig. 7, the μm values of the prepared sample has the highest amount of Bi2O3 (G5), and greater than GR1, GR2, GR3, GR4, and GR5 glass samples. The GR1 glass sample recorded the highest values of μm difference, while the lowest values of μm difference were reported for GR5 glass samples (Table 9 ).

The relation between HVL values of the investigated samples has been plotted in Fig. 8 . It is obvious that the HVL values increase as the energy increases up to 6 MeV. As the energy increases, the HVL values appear approximately constant. In the energy range of 0.15–0.2 MeV, the HVL values are less than 1 cm. On the other hand, the HVL values for all investigated glass samples decrease as the Bi2O3 concentration increases from 15 to 30 mol. % in the energy range 0.015–15 MeV. Fig. 8 observes that the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 (G5) glass sample has the lowest values of HVL. As shown in Fig. 9 the HVL values of the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 (G5) glass sample are the lowest for ordinary (OC), hematite-serpentine (HSC) and ilmenite concretes.

The calculated Zeff values against photon energy for the Bi2O3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 glass system have been plotted in Fig. 10 . This figure observes that all glass samples have a maximum value at low energy (0.01 MeV). For the Bi2O3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 glass system, the Zeff values are ranged from 12.07 to 15.40, 12.31 to 15.81, 12.54 to 16.20, 13.03 to 16.92 and 13.51 to 17.58 for G1, G2, G3, G4, and G5 glass samples, respectively. The Zeff values increase as the Bi2O3 contained increases from 15 to 30 mol. %. Therefore, the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample has the highest values of Zeff. When the photon energy is close to the K-absorption edges of the elements (Na, Si, Fe, Mo, and Bi) existent in the glasses, there are sudden changes in Zeff values, which are due to the jump in μm values at the elements’ K-absorption edge. This behavior has been confirmed in Table 10 , which indicates various values that correspond to elements K-absorption edge. Yalçın et al. [40] have announced that a relationship between photon energy and scattering angle cannot be neglected by researchers calculating the Zeff theoretically. Fig. 11 observes that the scattering angle parameter cannot be ignored in calculating Zeff, particularly at a small angle.

Table 11 lists the equivalent atomic number (Zeq), EBF and EABF G-P factor coefficients for the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass system. Figs. 12 and 13
show the EBF and EABF values against energy at different penetration depth for the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample (as examples), respectively. Due to the process of the photoelectric effect, the minimum EBF and EABF values of all glassy samples are found at low photon energy. At the intermediate energy region, the EBF and EABF values of glass samples increase up to the maximum as the photon energy increase. This behavior may be attributed to multiple scattering by Compton effect. At higher energy, the EBF and EABF values observed increasing behavior, which may be attributed to the pair production process. In addition, the sharp peaks that appeared may be due to K-absorption edges of high atomic number elements that exist in glassy samples. As shown in Figs. 12 and 13, the EBF and EABF values increase as the penetration depth increases for the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample. Figs. 14 and 15
observe the EBF and EABF values with photon energy for studied glass samples at 15 mpf. The 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample contains the highest amount of Bi2O3 (30 mol. %) and has the lowest EBF and EABF values at the energy range 0.015–15 MeV.

The ΣR measures the probability that fission energy or fast neutrons undergo first collisions, which removes them from the penetrating group. By the removal process, the neutron attenuation will be dominated if the glass samples have sufficient moderating elements. Not all neutron interactions change the energy or direction of the neutron sufficiently to occur a removal process, and the total neutron cross-section is greater than the effective removal cross-section. At the neutron energy range 2–12 MeV, the effective ΣR is considered to be approximately constant [25]. Eqs. (4) and (5) have been used to calculate the ΣR values for glass samples and are shown in Fig. 16 . It is clear that the ΣR values increase from 0.1051 to 0.1224 cm−1 as the Bi2O3 contained increases from 15 to 30 mol. %. Fig. 17 shows the ΣR values for the studied glasses compared to those of previous studied concretes and glasses. As observed in this figure, the ΣR values for samples are higher than that for ordinary concrete (OC) [29], hematite-serpentine concrete (HSC) [29], ilmenite concrete (IC) [29], 66B2O3-5Al2O3-29Na2O glass (GR1) [13] and 30SiO2-46.67B2O3-23.33Na2O glass (GR6) [11]. Finally, the ΣR value for the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 glass sample is the highest when comparing the ΣR values for all investigated glass samples, (OC, HSC, IC) concrete and (GR1, and GR6) glass. This means that the 30Bi2O3-40B2O3-20SiO2-9Na2O-1Fe2O3 shows favored gamma and neutron shielding properties when compared to other investigated glasses and concretes.

The fractal bond connectivity (d) is a valuable parameter that relates the glasses’ elastic properties to their structures. The d values give information about the effective dimensionality and cross-links of the glass network. The values of d can take the values 1 (chain), 2 (layer structure) and 3 (3D networks of tetrahedral coordination polyhedral) [41]. The d values, as listed in Fig. 18 , proposed that when the Bi2O3 content increases, the layer structure of the glassy samples will be transformed into the chain structure. The results of ρ, VL and VS ultrasonic velocities have been used to calculate the longitudinal (L), shear (G), bulk (K) and Young’s (E) modulus, of the glass samples [11]. Fig. 19 observes the experimental values of L, G, K, E for glass. As shown in Fig. 19, the experimental L, G, K, and E values of glass samples increase from 108.88 to 121.48 GPa, from 26.83 to 28.33 GPa, from 73.11 to 83.71 GPa and from 71.06 to 76.95 GPa, respectively, when increasing the content of Bi2O3 from 15 to 30 mol. %. This may due to the fact that the elastic moduli depend on the ρ values, which increase by an addition of Bi2O3 to the content, compacting the glass structure and increasing network rigidity.

The Bi2O3-B2O3-SiO2-Na2O-Fe2O3 glass system has been fabricated by the melt quenching technique with different Bi2O3 contents. The μm, HVL, Zeff, EBF, EABF, and ΣR values have been calculated. The XCOM, MCNPX code and XMuDat program have been used to calculate the μm. The effect of partial interaction on total μm values increases as the Bi2O3 contained increases from 15 to 30 mol. %. This revealed that the addition of Bi2O3 improves the ability of the glass sample to shield more photons. It can be concluded that obtained data of such investigation may help in synthesizing and modeling new Bi2O3 related glass systems which in turn are able to resist possible radiation hazard to the living biological structures.
The authors express their gratitude to the Deanship of Scientific Research, Majmaah University, Saudi Arabia, for funding this search work under Grant no. 1440-61.
